speaker: Commander Hayes
text: Hey there sleepy head. Sun's shining... hehehe

speaker: Commander Hayes
text: Okay yeah we've been on ice way longer than intended, like 2000 years, so you probably feel as crap as I do. And we're in the middle of nowhere. Untouched wilderness.

speaker: Commander Hayes
text: So lets just do a run and see if the equipment still works properly.

speaker: Commander Hayes
text: And by equipment I mean us...

speaker: Commander Hayes
text: I've uploaded coordinates for your first target. Use the navigation system to locate it.

speaker: Commander Hayes
text: Okaaaay. Basic brain function is looking goood. Now begin your investigation. Gather all the data you can.

speaker: Commander Hayes
text: We're a little slow but that's expected. All within tolenance. Now fill in your summary and send it off.

speaker: Commander Hayes
text: Great we seem to be in business. And I'm sure the brain fog will clear as we keep going. Lets do a few more.

speaker: Commander Hayes
text: Here's another one.

speaker: Commander Hayes
text: Fuck it looks like no one in key crew can figure out where we are.

speaker: Commander Hayes
text: And we're just finding mostly nonsense. Which makes sense I guess. We've flown off into infinity with a 3rd of the human race in a big fridge after all. But one thing doesn't sit right with me.

speaker: Commander Hayes
text: Why are there so few stars?

speaker: Commander Hayes
text: Keep sending those reports while I try to figure this out.

speaker: Commander Hayes
text: Is that.......a.......satelite?!

speaker: Commander Hayes
text: A HUMAN satelite?! At least I think it could be.

speaker: Commander Hayes
text: Quickly, see if there's anything else out there. I'll send a few probes and get down to the bottom of this.

speaker: Commander Hayes
text: A fucking satellite...

speaker: Commander Hayes
text: Had a look at the satellite. And yeah, it's human. Its so advanced I almost hestitate to say human.

speaker: Commander Hayes
text: I can't begin to think what this means. Just keep sending them through I suppose. I'll change my search algorithms to look for more of this kind of debris.

speaker: Commander Hayes
text: And see if you can find any dates on them so we can tell when their clocks stopped.

speaker: Commander Hayes
text: This clock stopped 54000 years after we left earth...

speaker: Commander Hayes
text: I guess our clock is a little off. My only guess could be that our ship encountered an extremely high gravity object and we've been essentially in stasis for a very long time.

speaker: Commander Hayes
text: Then there must be someone out here somewhere. Right??

speaker: Commander Hayes
text: Keep track of those timestamps and see how far this rabit hole goes. I'm gonna go print me a whiskey.

speaker: Commander Hayes
text: From studying the composition of the objects in your reports, Research is saying that trying to figure out what Time we are might be futile.

speaker: Commander Hayes
text: We've been out for so long that stars have died out. Galaxies have died out. And... our neighboring stars are out of reach of us.

speaker: Commander Hayes
text: All life that has existed has risen, fallen, and canibalized itself a million times over.

speaker: Commander Hayes
text: We're at the darkest pages of the story of the universe. And there's something worse than any horror out here.

speaker: Commander Hayes
text: Silence.

speaker: Commander Hayes
text: And what can we do but keep trying to find a home? Sigh. Your work is really great. I just feel... exhausted. I guess.
